definitions.definition: To set free , release or discharge (from obligations , debts , responsibility etc.).
examples: You will absolve a subject from his allegiance.

definitions.definition: To resolve ; to explain ; to solve .
definitions.dating_raw: Attested from the late 15 century until the mid 17 century.

definitions.definition: To pronounce free from or give absolution for a penalty , blame , or guilt .
definitions.dating_raw: First attested in the mid 16 century.

definitions.definition: To pronounce not guilty; to grant a pardon for.
definitions.dating_raw: First attested in the mid 16 century.

definitions.definition: To grant a remission of sin; to give absolution to.
definitions.dating_raw: First attested in the mid 16 century.

definitions.definition: To remit a sin; to give absolution for a sin.
definitions.dating_raw: First attested in the late 16 century.
Attested from the late 16 century until the early 19 century.

definitions.definition: To pass a course or test; to gain credit for a class; to qualify academically.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To set free , release or discharge (from obligations , debts , responsibility etc.). [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
secondary_definitions: ( transitive , obsolete ) To resolve ; to explain ; to solve . [Attested from the late 15 century until the mid 17 century.]
( transitive ) To pronounce free from or give absolution for a penalty , blame , or guilt . [First attested in the mid 16 century.]
( transitive , law ) To pronounce not guilty; to grant a pardon for. [First attested in the mid 16 century.]
( transitive , theology ) To grant a remission of sin; to give absolution to. [First attested in the mid 16 century.]
( transitive , theology ) To remit a sin; to give absolution for a sin. [First attested in the late 16 century.]
( transitive , obsolete ) To finish ; to accomplish . [Attested from the late 16 century until the early 19 century.]
( transitive ) To pass a course or test; to gain credit for a class; to qualify academically.
